bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, April 21, 1942

div1.p: Hench writes that he will soon be visiting Truby and Mabel Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, April 21, 1942
div1.opener:
April 21, 1942
Mr. George A. Kellogg
John F. Murray Advertising Agency
41 East 42 Street
New York City
My dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
All day the other day I expected a call from you. A long
distance call did come through and I was about to great you cheerily
when I found that the call was from some other city and another person.
Perhaps it was just as well as I was very busy with some extra work.

The McDowell painting is grand--perhaps the best yet so far
as color is concerned. The pastel shades are beautiful I think and it
is very effectively done. Looking at the determined yet thoughtful ex-
pression on McDowell's face, I couldn't help thinking of a title in
terms of “She must be well.” Of course, that isn't a very specific or
good title but it did come to mind.

I shall be indeed interested to see the little booklet of
the collected paintings and will be glad to go over the copy for the
yellow fever painting.

I am off to see Pinto, General Truby and Mrs. Lazear in three
or four days but will be home in two weeks.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
